text: Yeah, I mean, it all stems from what we learned in prospect theory. That's what it's about. Before prospect theory, risk aversion was king, a power law utility was king. And then once prospect theory came along, we learned that human beings, their risk profile is not well defined by a single power law utility with a singular parameter of risk aversion. And right when you start to incorporate prospect theory into the portfolio construction process, right, once you have a more advanced utility function than a power law utility, you start to have the potential for higher moments to become important. If you're just doing a power law utility invariance, it doesn't matter if the assets in your portfolio have a lot of skew, kurtosis, co-skew, whatever. But once you use a utility function that is sensitive to higher moments, like incorporating loss aversion, you will be sensitive to skew all of a sudden. That's how you get to the point where you say, okay, higher moments matter. It's post-prospect theory. And the entire world still lives in mean variance land. Whether they say it explicitly or not, everyone probably uses like a heuristic of five volatility buckets and an efficient frontier, or even 60-40 as like the middle vol bucket or whatever. Very heuristic. At the end of the day, that comes from mean variance. And so 95% plus of the world is somehow explicitly or not still just living in mean variance land. And they haven't updated their systems to account for prospect theory, which is from the seventies. So we're good, almost 50 years behind.
